user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ShellOutputToFile:
```c
int32 OS_ShellOutputToFile(const char *Cmd, osal_id_t filedes)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(Cmd);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_REFCOUNT, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM, filedes, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_ShellOutputToFile_Impl(&token, Cmd);
        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ShellOutputToFile:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
int32 OS_ShellOutputToFile_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const char *Cmd)
{
    return OS_ERR_NOT_IMPLEMENTED;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM 0x06
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
Rule 21.17 concerns use of the string.h functions (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.). A review of the provided code fragments shows no calls to any of these standard string handling functions:

- OS_ShellOutputToFile: only checks Cmd for NULL via OS_CHECK_POINTER and forwards Cmd to OS_ShellOutputToFile_Impl; there is no string manipulation here.
- OS_ShellOutputToFile_Impl: the provided definition simply returns OS_ERR_NOT_IMPLEMENTED and contains no string operations.
- OS_ObjectIdGetById, OS_ObjectIdRelease and the related macros/constants: these routines manipulate tokens, ids and control flow but contain no calls to string.h functions in the shown code.
- OS_CHECK_POINTER macro and other provided macros/typedefs do not invoke any string handling functions.

Because none of the provided fragments call or use the standard string.h functions, there are no code fragments in the supplied code that need to be investigated for Rule 21.17. (If OS_ShellOutputToFile_Impl or any of the referenced helper functions are implemented elsewhere, those implementations should be checked for string.h usage.)
